item.title: The situation is a bit similar to WWI.
item.description: https://x.com/MarekLada_/status/2004847044348002712 For those believing russia is actually gaining significant territory, it's not. The actual territorial gain since 2023 is close 5,000 km² that would come down to 160 russian casualties/km². If we extrapolate that for the rest of Ukraine (as a thought experiment, it does not work like that in the real world) at the current casualties/km² exchange rate, Russia would need to sacrifice roughly 1/3 to 1/2 of its entire male population to take the rest of Ukraine. Obviously this breaks down completely in practice—resistance stiffens near population centers, supply lines extend, mobilization capacity collapses, and the economy implodes long before those numbers. But it does illustrate why the "grind to total victory" strategy that would need another 90 years is mathematically absurd. Russia can't keep this up, on the other hand Ukraine needs Support from Europe (and others) to keep going until russia eventually collapses under the strain of the war they started. Slava Ukraine!

“Outside of the killings, DC has one of the lowest crime rates in the country.” - Marion Barry I try to keep my posts "good vibe zones". So, instead of finding the one thing in here you don't like and commenting only on that, also comment about something you DID like. Balance the negativity. Love you long time. So, I made a discord server. It's a relaxed environment where you can take/donate memes to the cause, play trivia twice a week, chat about lots of topics or about nothing at all. We also have Jack Box game night and are setting up movie night! Very laid back/relaxed vibe. Come hang with us. https://discord.gg/AWFV7FT3RQ I'm also on the imgcat server for updates & fun: https://discord.gg/TpjD37jgJ9 ***Also if you miss abbiistabbii's discord community good news! Here's the new one https://discord.gg/NPStJGgARq - where everyone's reconnecting, shitposting, and hanging out again*** https://ko-fi.com/mememuseumcurator Unable to work, zero income. Feel free to leave me a tip. Those that have, y'all are the bee's knees. You've honestly been my lifeline. ***Tag me if you see an artist/creator you like whose work isn't getting seen as much as it should be! Or if you are an artist/creator and want me to post something of yours, DM me!

item.title: A quick explanation of pregnancy, for people whose sex education lacks:
item.description:
Fun fact about pregnancy, when an egg is fertilized, you're already two weeks pregnant. Before the man becomes involved, a woman's body has already gotten to work. That should help to quiet some of those paternity cases. During a woman's menstrual cycle, the lining of the uterus (the endometrium) developed for the sake of housing offspring. If it doesn't, it throws an absolute fit. Tears down the wallpaper, squeezes like a bitch, and flushes the unused product down the toilet. It uses the fluid which we all have in abundance to do it: blood. Abdominal nursery unused? Clean it out for a chance next month. Let's say next month you put that to use. The woman's ovary drops an egg into the fallopian tube (with some help from squirm anatomy). The woman engages in a sexual encounter where sperms are injected into her vagina. That proceeds past the cervix and into the fallopian tube. Should they meet the egg, you have fertilization. That zygote now has the potential to grow a person. It doesn't always. Often that zygote is passed like an unused egg. Very often.
Sometimes the zygote is developed in the tube. Gets stuck. The tubal pregnancy. Hopefully this is discovered before it becomes life threatening, but it destroys the tube. Down to one. Or perhaps the zygote goes from the tube to the uterus. There's, maybe, it attaches to the endometrium. Sometimes it doesn't. Unlatched zygote, new period. But maybe it attaches. Zygote into the endometrium. Cells double, and double again. Some form the eventual fetus, some form the placenta for feeding the fetus. Sometimes it just forms the placenta. Cruel trick of fate. Sac, like a yolk, with no chick. Anatomy can be cruel.
Maybe it all works the way you wished, or you avoided, or you hated, or you feared. That zygote went and attached to the uterus with the intention of building a person. Your body did two weeks of work before the male was ever bedded, in prep. Bodies do things like that. Now you're building a person. It could kill you. It could ruin you. It could make you. It could elevate you. Who knows what the experience will do. You're building a person. But, gods, the stress. Your body is a selfish creature. It wants to keep going itself. If building a person is too taxing, why should it? How could you care for it in this state of stress, of starting a new medication, of stopping a medication, of being audacious to build when the wind blew wrong? Abort process, another spontaneous abortion. One third of pregnancies end in spontaneous abortions, also known as miscarriages. Solid one third. Usually in the first trimester. You are not told that because that very stress might feed the self fulfilling prophecy. But maybe your experience lasts the full nine months. You deliver a beautiful baby (there is a significant possibility that while you struggle to push out that baby, you'll push out a shit. Baby has been sitting on your innards for months. It does weird things, like prevent you from proper bathroom visits.) But you did it! Fresh baked baby! Get a Pic! I love fresh baked baby photos. So mad! “It's cold! It's bright! I hate this! Put me back!” a reasonable rage.
But now you look at your child. Some find an instant love affair. I don't think I've ever loved anything the way I loved my first baby. Visited her every day in the NICU. They're still an absolute badass to this day. Come my second round. I was convinced the entire process I could never love another child as I did my first born. I kept imagining a Sophie's choice analogy. My second child was beautiful. I am lucky to have loved her deeply from the moment I saw her.
Didn't stop the post party depression. All I wanted in the world was to be left alone. Their father was a soldier of little help during their infancy. And I started building a third to boot. The hormones that worked numbers on me were vicious and without rest. Three kids in three years. I do not recommend it. It's more stress than any person should volunteer for, especially with no help. I was miserable for years. Luckily my (probably autistic) need to adhere to the development regimen (EDIS) meant I kept my kids on pace. And then other kids as I was voluntold to raise them. Pregnancy starts before sex, and lingers far after birth. Anyone who tries to say something different is uneducated. Don't take your beliefs from uneducated fear mongers. They don't know the difference between vagina and uterus. Find a good doctor, and trust them. Not the idiot that thinks a dolphin is a human person.

item.title: Websites To Help You Feel Good
item.description: Feeling down about the state of the world? Need a little boost to keep you going through the day? Then try these websites! 1. Political Optimism: No other website has helped me more this past year than this one: it single-handily healed my doomer mindset and gave me more hope than anything else in 2025. I visit this site everyday, and my mental health is all the better for it. https://www.reddit.com/r/PoliticalOptimism/ 2. Good News Sites: Two great sites for a daily dose of good news from all around the world! https://www.goodnewsnetwork.org/ https://www.positive.news/ 3. Debunking Doomsday: A site dedicated to debunking sensationalist and exaggerated stories meant to inspire dread and terror. While this site has gotten some things wrong over the years (it predicted that Trump wouldn't become president, and that Putin wouldn't invade Ukraine), it still uses sound logic and reason to show why things aren't as bad as you think they might be. https://robertinventor.substack.com/ 4. Good Environmental News: The Climate Change situation is bad, but there are lots of reasons to have hope, and these two sites do a great job of bringing it to your inbox! https://happyeconews.com/ https://www.dailyclimate.org/Good-News/ 5. Draw Nebulas: There are tons of free games and stress-busting programs online. This one is my favorite. https://29a.ch/sandbox/2011/neonflames/# 6. Write Funny Messages In Old Video Games: Pretty self explanatory. https://deathgenerator.com/#gallery 7. An enormous index of Tolkien-related lore: Because you can never have enough Tolkien in your life. https://imgur.com/gallery/tolkien-lore-post-index-axV2mPF https://imgur.com/gallery/tolkien-lore-post-index-part-2-AQK9pJL 8. A huge collection of 'So Bad It's Good' songs: You're bound to find something that makes you laugh. And for even more fun, check out TVTropes' main 'So Bad It's Good' page (https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoBadItsGood) https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/SoBadItsGood/Music Remember: Search for the light, and once you've found it, share it with others.

item.title: A Year in the Life of a Trucker - 2025
item.description:
Time for me to recap another year that just went by. I think this year I've accomplished a lot, both professionally and personally.
Tumilik has always been the main star of the show. I think without her my almost daily postings wouldn't be the same.
One thing I really liked was having the opportunity for a delivery all the way back home, in New Brunswick, and getting a picture at the lighthouse. This here is a place I used to visit often as a child. And everytime I come back home for a few days, visiting my dad, family, and friends, I make sure to come down here. This here is the lighthouse at the end of the road on Miscou Island, at the northeasternmost point of the province of New Brunswick.
I've driven to a lot of places on Canada, once again.
Fueling the hell out of the truck!
Across the bridge to Prince Edward Island a few times.
Out west during peak forest fires. It gave that yellowish "Dune" vibe. The air tasted of smoke..I can't imagine how those with asthma and such managed to breathe during that time.
Downtown Toronto.
Ah, yes, Winnipeg.
Where we brought giant tanks for a new Costco.
Cochrane, Ontario. Did you know Tim Horton himself was originally from here in Cochrane, Ontario? There's even a Tim Horton exhibit at the local arena about him. Fun fact, he was part of the last Maple Leafs lineup to ever win the Stanley Cup. They've now been losers since 1967. They also have a tendency to choke when the games are important... Just like the Jays did in the World Series... Hah!
Somewhere in Ontario, near Drumbo.
I went up James Bay, to the Cree First Nations community of Wemindji.
I also went to the Atikamekw First Nations community of Manawan, where I met a lot of friendly "rez dogs".
This tank I brought to Manawan. I also hauled around a bunch of stuff, all over the country....
...like this reactor core, the black thing on the left, and a reactor bell.
All wrapped nicely for the drive.
Loaded a few tractors.
Hauled roofing materials.
Got busy farming.
Hauled farming dome structures.
More farm equipment.
Again, and again.
Hauled hay, hey!
Steel tanks.
Hauled pipes around.
Loaders and such.
I broke down a few times, and I'm usually able to fix myself. Here, power steering line ruptured.
Camping for the night in truckstops here and there.
Saw this near Moncton. Kinda neat. The trailer is a camping unit.
I had the opportunity, twice actually, to board the new ferryboat for Newfoundland.
This is one of my favourite places to drive. I love Newfoundland so much.
The good old MV Leif Ericson.
All in all, a fun year hauling a bunch of different stuff all over the country.
Deliveries only.
At home, I cooked a bunch of stuff, mostly Asian food, and more specifically Thai. It's really the cuisine I'm most drawn to.
Made some Chinese sesame beef.
Soviet food.
I dehydrated some mandarin peels which I will be able to use one day in some recipes. Those are good forever.
Grilled some birds.
Some occasional comfort food.
Canadian, eh.
I baked cookies a few times. These here are about the size of a hockey puck. Some said they were really good, but way too big. They were mostly made of butter and sugar.
Cookies are meant to be shared, according to her.
Had my occasional Guinness. I don't really like alcohol in general, but this stuff is good.
My friend's son got into Dungeons and Dragons this year, playing with friends at his high school. And at home, we have a thing going on with rubber ducks.. so I found him some dice with ducks inside.
Not a care in the world.
I'm either on the road, trucking around, or at home being bossed around by this dog. At home, in the hierarchy, I'm below Tumilik.
We got a garden going once again.
Friendly garden spider. Protector of the hot peppers we grew.
Our best one so far.
We grew large vegetables. The zucchinis succeeded well.
It gave us a lot of vegetables and hot peppers, as far as late October.
Grew Thai peppers, and made my own sweet chilli sauce. Extra peppers. Extra spicy.
We had the Snowbirds flying above us. Canada's iconic military aerobatic team. Nine Canadair CT-114 Tutors in perfect formation, white smoke across the sky. There's something powerful about seeing them in person.
Tumilik has a thing for sticks.
She knows some nest in the upper part of the garage.
I took some time off, enjoying my first vacation break in over three years. For this, I went back home in New Brunswick.
Tumilik became overly obsessed with squirrels this year.
Tumilik dragged along for the ride. She really enjoyed her time here. I did too, spending most of my time with my friend Mélanie.
21 March, 2025. I applied for the Canadian Armed Forces.
I did a whole bunch of tests, interviews, filled out forms, sent documents, provided this, and that. It's a very, very long process. As of end on 2025 I am still waiting on their final decision, yay or nay, if I can serve in the CAF. I'm on the very last step, waiting for the very last item to be checked.
Since March I've been training super hard for that. To be ready if I do get the call. One thing I did was going for ruck walks, with a weighted ruck sack.
I bought an old Canadian army ruck sack, and one that's been in Afghanistan nonetheless. Bought it from a retired member of the CAF, who served in Afghanistan.
As of now, I am currently walking between 6 and 12 kilometres, with 70 lbs on my back.
I also jog between 5 and 8 kilometres, and do a whole bunch if different callisthenics exercises.
I also picked up swimming when I heard it was a requirement for the army. Back in April I didn't even know how to float in a pool. Now, as of last week, I can swim sessions of two kilometres, front crawl. With now the added bonus of having an Ironman world-class athlete to give me training tips. She is an amazing athlete with an amazing down to earth personality.
This year I lost 45 pounds. I aimed for 170, and reached it in August. I was able to do this by combining my military training programme with a very harsh calorie restrictive diet.
Can't wait to hear from them! I've applied for "Mobile Support Equipment Operator", or, MSE Op for short.
Beautiful Tumilik, wearing her thick winter coat. Isn't she graceful?
For the Christmas holidays, I came back home in New Brunswick. I'm currently here and will stay until the start of January.
But vacations or not, ruck walking with 70 lbs on my back is still on. The holidays aren't an excuse to be lazy, although I do enjoy an extra treat, or two, or three.
This year's been a proper journey, hasn't it? So many ups and downs... I've poured everything into bettering myself, getting fitter, healthier, trying to become someone I can actually be proud of. Work's been a beast at times, honestly relentless, and 2025 has felt like one long, exhausting rollercoaster that I wasn't entirely sure I'd survive. But then something happened that I never saw coming. Right when I needed it most, when I was aching for someone close, someone who truly mattered, someone who could make me feel loved, wanted, like I wasn't just taking up space in the world, there she was. Mélanie. After all these years of friendship, something shifted, and suddenly she wasn't just my friend anymore. She became the person who reminded me what it feels like to be seen, to be held, to matter to someone who knows every version of me and chooses me anyway. I didn't know I needed that until she gave it to me. And now I can't imagine this year, or any year, without her in it.
We've been friends since 1995, way back when we were just kids in high school, figuring out who we were. From the very beginning, there was something between us that felt different, something I couldn't quite name but always knew was there. I remember the late 90s, talking on the phone every single night for three, four hours at a time, like the rest of the world didn't exist. But life had other plans for us. We never quite lined up, never found the right moment, so we stayed friends, year after year after year, each of us living our own lives, carrying our own weight. Still, whenever I'd come back home to New Brunswick, whether for holidays, work, or just passing through, I'd always make sure to see her, even if it was only for fifteen minutes. It didn't matter how brief the visit was... those moments mattered. She mattered. She's always had a special place in my heart, even when neither of us said it out loud. And now, we've been officially together since December 8th. After thirty years of friendship, we finally got the timing right. Our time, together. What we have is sincere, honest, true...a love that's endured the test of time, built on foundations we laid over a lifetime of knowing each other. I spent years searching for love across the world, chasing it in distant places, thinking it was somewhere out there waiting for me. Turns out, love was right here all along, back home, where I grew up, in the person who's known me longest and loved me anyway. And honestly, it feels amazing. For Christmas she gave me this cute little bracelet. I'm so not the type of person to wear such things. But, coming from her, it's ok. And I'm proudly wearing it.
But, love or not, I'm going to whoop her ass playing cribbage.
I cooked some of my famous beef and broccoli for Mélanie, and the gang here. They all loved it. I'll make some Korean food for them soon, and my absolutely delicious maple macaroni.
Shippagan, New Brunswick. This is where I'm from, and it always feels good to be back home.
Last swim of the year, and first time checking the regional pool here in Shippagan.
Not my picture because I don't think it's okay to take pictures when people are swimming..so I snatched one from their page. This here is salt water, and it's quite nice.
I do allow myself an occasional treat. With all those exercises, strict calorie restrictive diet and all, a once-in-a-while snack is most welcome.
And that is it for this year. Cheers!
Cadence to Arms Dropkick Murphys Driving around in Newfoundland.
Wild Cattieyote The Real McKenzies Boarding the ferry for Nova Scotia, on the Newfoundland side. Back when the clips were limited to 1 minute in length.
Do What You Want Bad Religion Somewhere in southern New Brunswick.
Jotunheim Moonsorrow The drive back from Manawan.
Druken Lullabies Flogging Molly Over the Confederation Bridge, from PEI to New Brunswick.
Trollhammaren Finntroll It's always a relaxing drive in the Maritimes. Here, we're in Charlottetown, PEI.
The Chase Is Better Than the Catch Motörhead A drive in northern Ontario.
Walpurgis Night The Coffinshakers Way up James Bay in Wemindji.
Ratamahatta Sepultura The joys of driving in Toronto.
Too Old Too Cold Darkthrone Out on the Prairies.
What?
